Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Forward Funding Year 1-4: Collaborative Research: Center for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
I/UCRC for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications

1034729 Ohio State University; Sudarsanam Babu
1034695 University of Wisconsin-Madison; Sindo Kou
1034703 Lehigh University; John DuPont
1034628 Colorado School of Mines; Stephen Liu

The Center for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications will focus on the diverse need for materials in energy industries, and on developing scientific methodologies to join these materials and predict their lifetime. Ohio State University (OSU), University of Wisconsin-Madison (UW), Lehigh University (LU) and Colorado School of Mines (CSM) are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with Ohio State University as the lead institution.

The intellectual merit of the proposed center is to "close the gap" between material development and weldability for materials used in the energy industry. The new knowledge generated will be used to (a) extend the life of material joints within the aging energy infrastructure and (b) increasing efficiency in deploying advanced materials for new energy infrastructure. The focus of the proposed center is to also address the critical need for engineering graduates trained in interdisciplinary methodologies to address materials joining for wide range of energy applications. The PIs are proposing the following research areas: joining of existing materials; joining of new advanced materials; joining of dissimilar materials; additive manufacturing for hybrid materials; and life extension of existing joints. The PIs are well-qualified and have adequate resources to conduct the proposed research.

The proposed center will focus on developing joining methodologies that will eventually become core components of the curriculum within welding and joining engineering programs. The proposed Center will also offer mentoring programs for students from different ethnic backgrounds and underrepresented groups. If successful, the scientific methodologies will be used to develop state-of-the-art simulation tools that could benefit several industries.

The defined concept for the center should provide an increase in the opportunity for different industries to participate in fundamental research. The center should provide an organized structure for drawing interest and projects from industry. In addition, the center should improve the potential for better understanding of advanced joining metallurgy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications (CIMJSEA) was established in 2010. The primary membership focus of the Center was on organizations and industrial companies involved in some aspect of the energy market including both producers and users of energy. The mission statement and objectives that were developed at the start of Phase I are as follows,

  • Close the gap between material development and weldability
  • Develop scientifically-based methodologies for assessing material weldability/joinability that span nm to mm length scales in order to 1) extend the life of welded structures within the aging energy infrastructure and 2) reduce the time and cost for deploying advanced materials (bulk materials, hybrid, advanced) for the new energy infrastructure
  • Develop a new generation of materials joining engineers and  scientists

The center has stimulated a renaissance in the US welding research community and the program has expanded to include many organizations outside the traditional energy field.  The center has grown to over 30 members from many different industry sectors including power generation, oil and gas, automotive, aerospace, defense, and primary metals.

There are currently five technology thrust areas within the Center, namely, 1) Material Performance, 2) Weldability Testing and Evaluation, 3) Modeling, 4) Process Development and Innovation, and 5) Additive Manufacturing. Over the duration of Phase I there were over 30 projects conducted under these thrust areas.

CIMJSEA has had a significant impact on the health and outlook for the national welding research and manufacturing community. At the end of Phase I, CIMJSEA ranked as the largest of the Phase I centers in terms of number of members and membership revenue. It also ranked in the top 10 overall among all 65 centers in terms of membership revenues. Membership remained stable over the last 2 years of Phase 1.

There are currently 15 researchers (faculty, research scientists, postdocs) and 24 graduate students active in the Center. Through the end of Phase I, 25 students will have graduated with advanced degrees (12 PhD and 13 MS). Approximately 25% of these students are now working for members organizations.  The center has had a significant impact on the materials science and welding communities. As an example, for the past 3 years over 20% of the papers presented in the annual American Welding Society Professional Program have come from Center-sponsored projects. Over 60 publications and 100 conference presentations have resulted from Center activity.

Other universities participating in Phase i were Lehigh University, Colorado School of Mines, and University of Wisconsin. The University of Tennessee, Knoxville was recently approved as a Phase I site and has joined the center. Also during this period, the Industry Advisory Board voted to change name of the Center at the transition to Phase II. The new center name, Manufacturing and Materials Joining Innovation Center (Ma2JIC) reflects the anticipated expansion of the center into more manufacturing-related research and the development of a broader research portfolio to meet national needs.  

 


Last Modified: 04/11/2016
Modified by: John C Lippold
